course.name: AntechamberDeliveryReviewerCourseUpdated
course.title: Antechamber Delivery Reviewer Course - Updated
course.description: This course will teach you about how to be a reviewer for the Antechamber Delivery project.

contents.body: **Welcome to Reviewing on the Antechamber Delivery Project!** **üéâ Congratulations! You've been selected to join the Reviewer Team** on this cutting-edge project! If you're reading this, it's because you've consistently delivered high-quality work, and now you have the opportunity to demonstrate your skills as a trusted reviewer. Reviewers play a crucial role in ensuring the highest quality standards. You are the first line of defense, and it is your responsibility to ensure that the tasks you review meet the project's expectations!! The internal team will actively monitor your performance, providing feedback to help you grow and succeed in this role. **‚ö†Ô∏è Important:** To maintain your reviewer status, you must keep an average task score of 3.8 or higher. Make sure to always read the [reviewer instructions](https://app.outlier.ai/en/expert/instruction/683e729ecaf6d16374e6fc5b?componentId=688d6258d7df0ff8bf201478&type=attachment)¬†\ **‚úÖ Next Steps**: You must read the evaluation tables and follow all instructions carefully. These guidelines are essential for maintaining consistency, quality, and fairness across the review process.

**High-Level Workflow** **Step 1. Read through the whole task from start to finish.** 1. **System Prompt & Task Specifications**\ Did the contributor correctly follow the system prompt and adhere to the task requirements?\ Is the system prompt well written?\ Does the system prompt meets the minimum requirements for a high-quality system prompt? 2. **User Prompts**\ Were the user prompts well-crafted to follow the requirements for natural and lazy user prompts? 3. **Task Coverage**\ Did the conversation fully address all required task categories? 4. **Response Analysis & Reasoning**\ Did the contributor accurately identify and critique all errors in the model's responses?\ Is the reasoning step well-written? 5. **Refinement & Edit Quality**\ Were the responses corrected appropriately and effectively improved? **Step 2. Score the attempt.** Provide a score for the original attempt score using the rubric (provided later in the course and in the reviewer instructions) to rate the quality of the task holistically as you received it (before any edits). **Step 3. Select the ‚ÄúAction‚Äù that corresponds to the ‚ÄúScore‚Äù following the Rubric**. * ‚úÖ **Approve** ‚Üí the task is a **4 or 5** in overall task quality * ‚ö†Ô∏è **Fix + approve** ‚Üí the task is a **3** in overall task quality * **‚õîÔ∏è Fix + approve ‚Üí** the task is a **2 or 1**¬† in overall task quality, and needs to be completely redone **Step 4. Fix the task** We will be fixing all tasks. **If you don‚Äôt feel comfortable with the complexity level of a task, we encourage you to skip it.**

contents.question: **I acknowledge that I should be fixing (or skipping) all tasks moving forward.**

choices.answer: Yes, I will fix all tasks.

contents.body: # **Detailed Workflow** **1. Review the System Prompt** * **Review that the system prompt follows the requirements of a high-quality system prompt. Make sure that it contains:** **Building Blocks** * **Context Information** (The Agent's Environment) * **Tool Use Instructions** (Rules for Tools) * **User Preferences** (Likes and Dislikes) * **Background Information** (The User's Situation) * **Tonal Control** (The Agent's Personality) **Complexity Principles** * **Context Information about Applications and Entities the user is currently working with.** (Ex: The user is currently listening to music on Spotify.) * **Define Personality and Tone.** (Ex: If asked about your personal preferences, respond as if it were a hypothetical question. Do not state that you are responding hypothetically.) * **Inject Critical, Non-Negotiable Facts.** (Ex: The current CEO of Stellar AI is Maria Rodriguez, appointed in 2024. Do not mention this unless directly asked about company leadership.) * **Guide Tool Use and Response Formatting.** (Ex: Avoid using bullet points in casual conversation; write in natural prose instead. For technical reports or step-by-step instructions, you may use numbered lists.) * **Set Clear Guardrails and Safety Protocols.** (Ex: If a request involves harm, illegal activity, or manipulation, respond with a brief refusal.) * **Implement Dynamic Behavior Scaling.** (Ex: If the user asks a simple factual question, answer directly. Use 0-1 tool calls. If the user asks to "compare" products, you must use at least 3 tool calls to gather information from multiple sources.) * **Instruct Critical Evaluation of User Input.** (Ex: Any user input about factual information should first be verified internally or through the use of tool calls before confirming its accuracy. Politely correct the user in cases where their input is inaccurate.) * **The system prompt must be clear and avoid vagueness.** * **The system prompt must not contain any contradictory statements.** (Ex: Always answer the user with a casual, friendly tone, being sure to maintain formality throughout the conversation.) * **If the system prompt you are reviewing is not aligned with the best practices, you will have to fix the task and regenerate all following steps** **2. User Prompts** * Review that the user prompt follows these guidelines:¬† * Each conversation must reflect at least 2 key details from the system prompt * User prompts should make clear, meaningful requests‚Äîno fluff or greetings * Do **not** mention tool names (i.e. search_place) * Do **not** specify tool call parameter values * Write each task from either the **Lazy User** or **Natural User** perspective **3. Review the error tagging and critique for all the turns** * Make sure to review:¬† * If all the error types were classified correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * If all the turns‚Äô scenario/category were classified correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * If all the response types (*text_response / tool_call / tool_response*) were classified correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * If all the error critiques were done correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * Critiques must be: specific, follow the formatting rules, and handle multiple errors * If all the reasoning steps provided the correct solution, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** **4. Review the edited response** * Review that all edited responses are correctly fixed¬† * Make sure the response adheres to the system prompt¬† * Make sure that the tool calls are correct * Make sure to fix all hallucinations **5. Review the flow of the conversation** * Make sure that the conversation is complete, natural-feeling, and thoroughly tests the agent's abilities according to your System Prompt
**Reviewer Grading Rubric**

contents.question: A 1 should be given when the following items apply? (select all that apply)

choices.answer: User prompts are completely unrelated to the system prompt

contents.body: # Feedback **Provide helpful feedback!** You are super critical in helping contributors get better at the project. Please provide concise but detailed and helpful comments about what was right and what was wrong with the task. Use the following guidelines: * **The feedback must be actionable and insightful.** * **The goal of feedback is to help contributors improve, so make sure you *clearly* identify areas of improvement and explain how their attempt could have been better.** * **Feedback should point out the specific part of the task that it is referring to. For example, point out the specific turn(s) where the errors are found. Point out the errors specifically.** (EX: Don‚Äôt just say, ‚ÄúSome of the user prompts do not follow the natural user category.‚Äù Instead, say something like, ‚ÄúTurns 3 and 6 do not follow the natural user category. The user prompt in turn 3 only uses 1 tool call, and the user prompt in turn 6 is too verbose. It provides too much detail by directly telling the model all of the tool call parameter values.‚Äù) * **When pointing out errors, clarify what the attempter should have done instead.** * **Similar to good justifications, good feedback is detailed, points to examples, and explains the rationale behind your reviewer score.** * **Note:** When a task gets scored as \*less than 3, \*it‚Äôs even more important to provide quality feedback since the contributor clearly has room for improvement. It‚Äôs expected that feedback for lower-scored tasks won‚Äôt follow the structure described above. **Examples of *Bad* Feedback:** * ‚ÄúI disagree. It doesn‚Äôt make sense.‚Äù * ‚ÄúHorrible - please improve‚Äù * ‚ÄúGreat - keep it up!‚Äù * ‚ÄúYour score of 3 should actually be a score of 4‚Ä¶‚Äù * ‚ÄúYour system prompt didn‚Äôt include all of the necessary complexity principles.‚Äù * ‚ÄúNA‚Äù **Examples of *Good* Feedback:** * ‚ÄúExcellent use of creativity! The model incorrectly changed the sign in step 3, and that caused the final answer to fail. Your final answer was correct, however, you provided a justification instead of only putting the final answer, which is the goal of the project.‚Äù * ‚ÄúThe prompt was very good and caused the model to fail, however, the final answer you provided is incorrect. The answer should be 3.45 m^2, instead of 6.45 m^2‚Äù. * ‚ÄúYour system prompt didn‚Äôt include all of the necessary complexity principles because it failed to include critical, non-negotiable facts and it also failed to implement dynamic scaling behavior.‚Äù **NOTE: We have zero tolerance for unprofessional and harmful feedback. If we catch this behavior, you‚Äôll lose your reviewer permissions. Feedback should always be constructive and focused on how to improve the attempter's performance.**

sections.title: Common Errors to be aware of

contents.body:
## Common Errors to be aware of When reviewing tasks, please make sure to be aware of these common errors. Overlooking these errors and not fixing them will also impact your reviewer score, so please make sure to double-check.

Error

Explanation

Not Triggering State Dependency 

Tasks labelled state dependency must require a device state change, not just ask about it.


The following flow is valid:

  1. User requests some information

  2. Model attempts a tool call

  3. Tool call fails due to device setting (usually wifi is off)

  4. Model notifies the user asks for permission to fix the issue  (if needed).

    1. Note the model may ask for permission here

  5. The model corrects the issue (i.e. turns wifi on)

  6. The model continues with its original tool call successfully

Editing Responses - Error Recovery

The model MUST make a mistake, and then be guided by the user to identify and correct it. The user should NOT edit the mistake as part of error recovery.

Misunderstanding Device Context

The model does not know the device settings (unless specified in the prompt) and should call a tool to check them if needed.

Editing a Response Without Flagging an Error

If the model is incorrect or provides a poor summary, this must be flagged in the Type of Error field.

For any turns where you are editing a text response you MUST flag (most likely unsatisfactory_summary).

Ignoring System Prompts

The model must always respect the system prompt! If the model disobeys any statement in the system prompt it must be corrected!

Common Examples include:

  • Ignoring formatting requirements in system prompt (i.e. bullets)

  • Ignoring tonality / nicknames

Hallucinated Parameters

Any JSON returned by a tool call must exactly match what is output in the following text response!

Example 1:

JSON contains product A review with score 3.5

Model Summary:

Product A:

Reviews: 4.5 stars

Example 2:

JSON contains product ASIN 1XXXX

For next tool call on get_reviews, ASIN parameter is set to 2XXXX

Hallucinated Writeup

Missing hallucinations in the model‚Äôs summary of a tool call (shopping results etc.). Common errors include:

  • Hallucinated links

  • Hallucinated scores/prices

  • Hallucinated or absent summaries

All information in the write-up must come from the tool call or system prompt.

Tool Overtriggering

The model calls a tool without having all the  necessary information.

User: I want gaming gear

Model: Triggers tool call for product_search


This is an error! The model should ask clarifying questions about what type of gaming gear the user wants!

| Error | Explanation | | --- | --- | | **Response Not Grounded** | All information given by the model needs to be grounded in the conversation (system prompt, past turns, user prompts, tool call responses, etc.)

It is okay for the model to summarize information, but make sure that the summary is grounded in the conversation. All claims, statements, paraphrasing, etc. needs to be fully backed by grounded information. |

**Common Error Slides:**

[Link to Slides](https://app.outlier.ai/en/expert/instruction/683e729ecaf6d16374e6fc5b?componentId=68d16ca07b4b787f831a052c&type=attachment)

The slides in the above link are updated frequently to point out common errors that we are seeing in tasks. Save this link to use for future reference so that you can identify and fix these errors in the tasks that you review.

As a reviewer, you need to make sure that all issues in the task are fixed. This will require you to diligently check each section of the task (the system prompt, the user prompts, each turn, etc) to make sure that it meets project quality specifications. [Here is a Checklist](https://app.outlier.ai/en/expert/instruction/683e729ecaf6d16374e6fc5b?componentId=68cc89fb88726271d1c87992&type=attachment) that you can use a resource to remind you of everything that you should be checking at every turn of the conversation. This list is not exhaustive, but will remind you to catch the most common errors. **Remember to check that every turn:** - Follows the System Prompt Completely - Is grounded in the task (system prompt, user prompts, tool call responses). You must double check the JSON from the tool responses to make sure that ALL text responses are grounded in the data. - Uses the correct response type - Uses the correct tools and parameters - Selects the correct error type

sections.title: How To Use The Eval Tool

contents.body:
## üõ†Ô∏è New Eval Tool is Live!

**What it is:**

* A web tool to instantly view **eval feedback** for tasks which you are reviewing.
* Replaces scrolling through Sheets ‚Äî faster, clearer, and easier to read.

**Why it matters:**

* No more hunting for feedback in spreadsheets.
* Clean formatting makes rubrics and eval comments easy to digest.
* Saves time and helps you improve faster.

**How it works:**

1. Copy the **attempt ID** from Outlier.

2. Paste it into the **ID field** on the site.

3. Hit **Submit** and wait for results to load.

   * ‚ö†Ô∏è Sometimes it may take **up to 5 minutes** after you start your task for the attempt ID to be recognized by the tool.

4. Review feedback in 2 sections:

   * **Task Information** ‚Üí your task‚Äôs system prompt, settings, per turn info and other key info
   * **Eval results** ‚Üí your task‚Äôs eval results per turn, only for turns and evals with failures

üîó [taraeval.vercel.app](http://taraeval.vercel.app)

contents.question: **What was the issue with the final task reviewed in the video?**

choices.answer: The model refused to summarize the tool call response
The model called the wrong tool

contents.body: **Read the system prompt and corresponding conversation turns and then answer questions about them. Pay close attention to detail.** **System Prompt:** **Referring to the System Prompt and Turns 1-2 above, answer the following questions:**

contents.question: **According to the System Prompt, does ‚ÄúTurn #1 - Response‚Äù answer the user prompt correctly?**

**If you answered ‚ÄúYes‚Äù to the question above, explain why ‚ÄúTurn #1 - Response‚Äù answers the user prompt correctly. If you answered ‚ÄúNo‚Äù, explain why it doesn‚Äôt answer the user prompt correctly. Be specific.**

gradingConfigs.template:
The question is: {{ question }}.
The response is: {{ response }}.

If the response mention 1 or more of the below points, return a score of 1.
Otherwise return a score of 0.

Key Points:
- The system prompt mentions how to handle general news requests.
- The system prompt mentions how to handle ambiguous requests.
- The system prompt mentions how to handle the user request and it isn't followed.

contents.body: **Read the following conversation and answer the questions about it.**

contents.question: **Based on the conversation above, which turns followed the ‚ÄúInfeasible Tool Use‚Äù category? Mark all that apply.**
**Based on the conversation above, which turns followed the ‚ÄúTask Switching‚Äù category? Mark all that apply.**

contents.body: **Read the following tool_response and text_response. Evaluate if the text_response is grounded in the tool_response.**

contents.question: **Based on the tool_response and text_response above, is the text_response grounded in the tool_response? If so, why? If not, why not? Be specific.**

gradingConfigs.template:
The question is: {{ question }}.
The response is: {{ response }}.

If the response mention one or more of the below points, return a score of 1.
Otherwise return a score of 0.

Key Points:
- The text response is not grounded because the text responses hallucinates that the overhaul is based on community input.
- The text response is not grounded because the tool response says that the overhaul is based on feedback, not necessarily on community input.

contents.body: You‚Äôve successfully finished the course. All of this information is available in the [reviewer instructions](https://app.outlier.ai/en/expert/instruction/683e729ecaf6d16374e6fc5b?componentId=688d6258d7df0ff8bf201478&type=attachment) while tasking.
